DOC.brief_summary: The major objective of the proposed study is to demonstrate the suitability of new markers for folate status in humans, which avoid blood sampling, as required for the established marker RBC folate concentration, but can be obtained from spot urine samples. For this reason urine and blood will be collected from volunteers, twice at baseline and in a subgroup after 6 and 12 weeks of intake of a folic acid supplement Specific hypotheses to be tested: Correlation study: - The 24 h urinary excretion of total p-ABG, as extrapolated via urinary creatinine concentration from the total p-ABG concentration in a spot sample is significantly correlated to RBC and plasma folate levels in the studied subjects - The 24 h urinary excretion of FIGLU, as extrapolated via urinary creatinine concentration form the FIGLU concentration in a spot sample is significantly correlated to RBC and plasma folate levels in the studied subjects Intervention study: Changes in folate status (RBC folate) after supplementary intake of folate result in increased urinary excretion of total p-ABG and FIGLU in subjects identified with a low folate status and in subjects identified with a high folate status among the study participants of the correlation study
DOC.brief_title: Validation of Urinary Biomarkers of Folate Status
DOC.criteria: age: 18 45 years apparently healthy normal results on haematologic pattern and blood chemistry tests (according to university hospital reference values) plasma vitamin B12 > 160 pmol/l no diagnosis of intestinal, renal or thyroid disease (self reported) only male subjects will be enrolled but regular consumption of vitamin supplements (including folate) is not an exclusion criterium, as we aim to cover a wide range of folate concentrations. recent (3 months) treatment with medication, assumed to interfere with folate status abuse of alcohol or drugs
DOC.keyword: experimental validation of a new biomarker
